label.text: Biological Control
A weed is a plant that is growing in an area where it is unwanted, such as among farmed plants.
Farmers try to control weeds using a variety of methods because weeds compete with farmed plants for resources such as sunlight, nutrients, and water.
Biological control is when an organism (such as a weed) is controlled by the introduction of a biological agent. Examples of biological control agents include:
animals that eat weeds, such as insects
pathogens that are harmful to weeds, such as bacteria and fungi.
The graph below shows a simulation of the effect of introducing a biological control agent on weed and farmed plant densities.
The weed damage threshold refers to the maximum acceptable level of damage to the farmed plant by the weed.
Weed damage threshold
weed
biological control agent
farmed plant
When choosing a biological control agent to help control a weed species, which characteristic must the weed and other plant species share?
life span
growth rate
types of nutrient
growing location
What causes the population density of the biological control agent to increase?
Use the graph to determine the correct answer.
an increase in the farmed plant density
a decrease in the farmed plant density
an increase in the weed density
a decrease in the weed density
Consider the following consequences of using a biological control agent.
Which of these are unwanted consequences?
Select all correct answers.
The biological control agent may begin to cause environmental damage.
The biological control agent may introduce disease to other organisms in the environment.
The biological control agent may survive and reproduce when weed density is very low.
The biological control agent may not control the weed enough for the farmed plant population density to exceed the weed damage threshold.
The graph shows that the biological control agent density lags behind the weed density.
Explain the reason for this.
A farmer uses four insect species to reduce the population density of one weed species on the farm.
What advantages might this approach have compared to using one insect species?
Select all correct answers.
Different insect species might feed on different plants.
Different insect species might be active at different times of the year.
Different insect species might target different stages of the weed’s life cycle.
Different insect species might feed on different parts of the plant, such as roots, stems and leaves.
A farmer finds that introducing an insect species into the fields as a biological control agent causes a large decrease in the weed density.
The farmer then sprays insecticide to kill the introduced insects.
Which one of the following statements about using insecticide to kill the introduced insects is correct?
It is harmful because the introduced insects are a natural part of the local food web.
It is unnecessary because the introduced insects will all die off when weed density is low.
It is not useful because there will be no introduced insects to control the weeds if the weed density increases.
It is useful because the introduced insects are no longer needed.
